instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2530: What is 820-2530? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.D6905: What is D6905? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input on very old Macbooks(before 2011), can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.ISL6258: What is ISL6258? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2008 through 2009.
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.R7021: What is R7021? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>

Some slight liquid damage signs around rear edge. 

Thought ok probably damaged 3v42 line. Check it getting 3.38V seems low. No obvious damage around the boost IC. 

Checked ACOK line from <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> 0v
Check ACIN 0v
Replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> due to internal short pulling ACIN low. 

Now have 4v on ACIN and ACOK reads 3.3v

Still dim green light. Also inrush MOSFET first gate isn't opening, so no <SIGNAL>PP_G3H</SIGNAL> being made either. 

Is this still a <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> issue or is the 3v42 too low causing a weird issue. 
​​​​
DCIN is 16.6 -16.8v and fluctuates quite a bit not a steady voltage

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light
threads.message: Sense resistor circuit checked? Resistance between pins 17/18 27/28?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light
threads.message:
17/18 21 ohm 27/28 - 33 Mohm

Replaced 27/28 now reading 20 ohm. Still dim green light and no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light
threads.message: ACOK line is back at 0V again

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light
threads.message:
18v5 input from DCIN keeps going from 16.1 to 16.6V it will slowly rise and fall.

I pulled <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, <DIODE>D6905</DIODE>, and <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> to see if would settle and its still bouncing. Tried 3 different DCIN boards and 3 different chargers. DCIN Rail reads OL in resistance and diode mode

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light
threads.message: Did you use a <CHIP>ISL6258</CHIP> and not a 6259? What is resistance to GND on ACOK?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light
threads.message:
Yes <CHIP>ISL6258</CHIP>. I double checked after I pulled the first one. Ill get you a reading on ACOK line. Doesnt make sense to me that voltage on DCIN isnt holding constant. I asked Louis on live stream and he said it should be a steady voltage 

Having removed <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, <DIODE>D6905</DIODE>, and <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> I was hoping to see this voltage stabilize but its still moving almost a full volt. Ill try a 3rd charging brick Monday to confirm that fully. Although the one I use on my other 13inch 2011 60W works just fine.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light
threads.message: Only thing needed for ACOK to come high is a good 6258 and power to pins 19, 20 and 3.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light
threads.message:
ACOK reads 0.5 Mohm 

Ill throw everything back on today and start messing with it again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light
threads.message: Replaced SMC getting solid green light now but AGate pin 1 isnt opening the inrush mosfet. I have 16.4-16.9 on source and same voltage on the gate. No output to Drain.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light
threads.message: ISL is not soldered properly or it is bad...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light
threads.message: SMC has a short under it. Reballed and its back to the same issues. Im about ready to give up on it

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light
threads.message: SMC does not just get a short under it. Is there a green light now?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light
threads.message:
Still Dim green light but ACOK and 3v42 present

What doesnt make sense is ACOK is showing up 3.3v but there is no power on the Inrush pins from charger.
The AGate is at 16.7v (DCIN voltage) but the Mosfet is closed. Is this a voltage divider that must go to ground on AGate to make the first Mosfet open? I replaced the mosfet to rule out that and no change.
There are no shorts on the inrush line to <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. ACOK reads in the MegaOhms and Ive replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> with a 6258 chip 4 times.
DCIN voltage isnt consistent it fluctuates from 16.2-16.9v. 3 different chargers all the same. 3 different DCIN boards all the same.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light
threads.message: I would say the SMC is bad too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light
threads.message: Ill replace it again. I pulled one from another board and installed it but idk its condition. Ill snag another and try again

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light
threads.message:
Well Im back to this one. Replaced SMC and getting green light now but still dont have a switch from <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> to open the inrush mosfet to start making <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

This is supposed to switch to ground correct so the voltage divider drops gate voltage low and opens?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light
threads.message:
I confirmed that yes AGATE goes to ground to allow voltage in. 

I pulled the chip and ACOK is still there I guess because this is a data line. So charger light is green. 

Correct me if Im wrong but you get power on the computer.

3v3 and 3.42 lines come up with the charger. 
3v3 feeds the ACOK line
3v42 and ACOK 3v3 tell SMC when the charger is preset along with the ACIN pin allows <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> internally to work This should cause SMC to tell <CHIP>ISL6258</CHIP> to ground the AGATE line and inrush mosfet opens. 

Im not sure what part is broken here Ive put 3 SMCs on it and the data lines from SMC to <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> are 3v or higher. 
I cant imagine Ive installed every one of these ISL6258s wrong (Orientation is correct) and I cant imagine I have 3 bad SMCs.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light
threads.message:
Well I feel dumb. The Diode that feeds Charger DCIN pin 2 of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> died and wasnt allowed 16v through.

I get boot on SMC bypass so I should be able to swap it and be ready to go.

Now I know what to look for

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light
threads.message: Check all sense resistors and traces <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>/22/51/52 and <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light
threads.message:
Im getting boot now Duke but the voltage on inrush going to <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>/22 on intial plug in will go to 16.8 then falls but if I twist the charger connection it will jump back up to 16.8. I have to do this a few times then it will hold 16.8 and boots up fine.

I tried new charger and DCIN board. Not sure whats causing that

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light
threads.message: Could be bad <TRANSISTOR>Q7000</TRANSISTOR>/1. Did you check the resistance again between pins 17/18, 27/28 and check <RESISTOR>R7040</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light
threads.message: Yes rechecked resistance. They are good. Ill check <RESISTOR>R7040</RESISTOR> and the mosfets. Thank you Duke

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light
threads.message:
With battery connected I seem to get proper boot everytime so not too worried about the boot without batt being inconsistant.

Issue is down to a temp sensor which ASD shows as being the Internal Die CPU temp sensor having an issue and causing fan to run on high. Is there a way to fix this or could I somehow just redirect the temp data from another line over that reads good?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dim green light
threads.message: Is that the only sensor failing? It is <CHIP>U5515</CHIP> reading the diode in the CPU. So either bad <CHIP>U5515</CHIP> or CPU or cracked trace under CPU
